Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Spectrum Sensing, Allocation, and Charging for Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to conduct a holistic protocol design for large-scale cognitive radio networks. To support a large number of wireless devices as secondary users that able to dynamically access available channels, it is necessary to design decentralized architecture and solutions for cognitive radio networks. Based on the decentralized architecture, this project addresses important problems in spectrum sensing, spectrum allocation and pricing, and spectrum usage monitoring and charging in dynamic spectrum access networks. More specifically, this project focuses on three research thrusts: (1) A robust collaborative spectrum sensing algorithm to tolerate arbitrary false data reports from adversaries, (2) An efficient spectrum allocation and pricing scheme for a large number of secondary users to share spectrum resources based on localized and approximation algorithms, and (3) A scheme for monitoring and charging the spectrum usage of secondary users without sacrificing secondary users' privacy.

The proposed architecture and the solutions to the relevant problems have the potential to significantly advance the state-of-the-art of cognitive radio networking research, in particular, in improving the efficiency of spectrum sharing. The technology developed in this project will facilitate a wide variety of scientific and engineering applications and result in a significant impact on the society. The project will perform a wide range of education and outreach activities, including integration of research findings into courses and curricula, and involving under-represented students in research projects. Research results will be broadly disseminated through conference and journal publications, research talks, and via the Internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless spectrum is a scarce resource that our society will increasingly depend on for unprecedentedly high bandwidth communications. To realize the full potential what the spectrum can offer, the dynamic spectrum access (DSA) network has to be designed so that the spectrum resource management will be robust, efficient, and secure. 

This project aims to build a dynamic spectrum access (DSA) network based on a decentralized architecture so that management decisions will be made in a local level. This type of solution will be able to scale to a large number of devices in terms of computation, communication, and information collection and sharing. More importantly, decentralized approach will be able to obtain more information in a local level and share the information more rapidly.

More specifically, this project uses locally deployed stations to perform spectrum management. The wireless stations can be separately deployed or embedded in wireless devices. Those distributed stations can cooperatively sense the availability of the spectrum, allocate spectrum to devices, monitor the spectrum usage, and charge secondary users accordingly.  This architecture has two advantages. First, the scheme is highly scalable without relying on a central server. Second, the stations can easily monitor spectrum usage and ensure devices follow policies. Based on this decentralized architecture, the project provides support for more robust, efficient, and secure resource management systems.  

The project identifies three important components in DSA networks and provides corresponding solutions: spectrum sensing, spectrum allocation, and spectrum usage charging. The system is composed of the following components: (1) Cooperative sensing, a robust collaborative scheme which can tolerate false data report. (2) Spectrum allocation, a scheme to determine how to allocate spectrum resources to many devices. (3) Spectrum usage charging, a scheme in which the spectrum owners can verify the payment based on the spectrum usage without the hassle of knowing all the details. All these problems are significant in designing and deploying DSA networks. 

The provided solutions to the proposed problems consider different perspectives in addressing the issues toward better robustness, efficiency, and security. The effectiveness of the research methods were proved through theoretical analysis and practical experimental evaluation. 

During the NSF grant, the project supported six PhD students, three undergraduate students, and two high school students for research. More than 20 papers have been published. Collaboration between William & Mary and historically black college and university (HBCUs) was built and resulted in publications.
